title: Foreshadowing & Flashback Quiz
description: Learn how writers use foreshadowing and flashback to create suspense and depth in storytelling

questions.question: What is 'foreshadowing' in literature?
options: A hint or clue about events that will happen later in the story
The shadow of a character in a scene
The final scene of a story

questions.question: What is a 'flashback'?
options: A scene that interrupts the present narrative to depict events from the past
A bright flash of light in a story

questions.question: In a story, dark storm clouds gathering before a character faces a difficult challenge is an example of:
A character suddenly remembers a childhood event that explains their current fear. This is an example of:
What is a 'flash-forward'?
options: The first sentence of a story
The same thing as a flashback
A scene that jumps ahead to show events that will happen in the future

questions.question: Chekhov's Gun is a principle of foreshadowing. What does it state?
options: If a gun is shown in the first act, it must be fired by the final act

questions.question: Why do authors use flashbacks?
options: To provide background, reveal character motivation, or explain current events

questions.question: A character says, 'Enjoy this peaceful moment while it lasts.' This line serves as:
What is 'direct foreshadowing'?
options: A character's dream about the past
An explicit statement or clear warning about what will happen

questions.question: What is 'indirect foreshadowing'?
options: Using subtle hints, symbolism, or mood to suggest future events
Going back in time within the story
Telling the reader exactly what will happen

questions.question: In Shakespeare's 'Julius Caesar,' Caesar's wife dreams of his statue spouting blood. This is an example of:
What is the narrative purpose of a 'prologue' that shows a future scene before the story begins?
options: To serve as a dedication page
To create suspense by foreshadowing how the story will develop
To introduce all characters at once

questions.question: A broken mirror appearing in a story might foreshadow:
options: Bad luck, broken relationships, or shattered identity

questions.question: What is the difference between foreshadowing and a 'red herring'?
options: Foreshadowing hints at real future events; a red herring is a misleading clue
A red herring always involves fish
Foreshadowing is only used in poetry

questions.question: In film and literature, the phrase 'in medias res' relates to flashback because:
options: It means the story has no beginning
It means starting with a flashback
It means starting in the middle of the action, often requiring flashbacks to fill in earlier events
